author: Vivek Narayanan
text:
During the workshop organised by the traffic police at the Adyar bus depot on Thursday, MTC bus drivers bared their hearts and discussed issues that bothered them.

Many of them pointed out that city stretches posed a huge challenge today, as the traffic volume was rising exponentially.

They said that as a result of having to navigate roads that were choc-a-block with vehicles and that had shrunk owing to infrastructure projects, bus drivers were facing severe stress, which resulted from having to beat all these odds and reach the destination on time, they added.

Over 3,700 buses are operated on 850 routes, serving over 50 lakh passengers every day. Each driver does at least eight trips a day. The shortest duration of a trip is 40 minutes and the longest is close to two hours. “On an average, we drive 380 kilometres every day,” drivers who attended the workshop said. The stress largely derives from having to reach destinations on time. Many drivers said that they were forced to drive fast owing to the timings, which, they claimed, were outdated.

Sources said travel duration fixed for various routes over 45 years ago were still being followed. Sources said that a study was carried out by the MTC a few years ago that concluded that increasing the duration of every trip could help reduce stress levels.
title: Stress levels peak with traffic snarls
